Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: IOC collaborates with UN specialized agencies and international organizations related to marine sciences. It acts as a joint mechanism for UN organizations in marine science fields, fostering cooperation and ensuring that its requirements are considered in their programs​​. The IOC supports its mission through institutional relationships. It collaborates closely with the UNESCO, as the IOC functions as a specialized agency within UNESCO, detailed in Article 1-10 of the IOC’s statutes (). The IOC also partners with the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) to advance global oceanographic and atmospheric research, as outlined in the collaborative agreement between the two entities . Furthermore, the IOC works in conjunction with the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) to address marine environmental issues, with cooperation terms specified in the agreement between IOC and UNEP _EAF_CP6_BUR.DOC_6%20MOU%20between%20IOC%20&%20UNEP.pdf?sequence=1&amp%3BisAllowed=). The IOC’s engagement with FAO, IAEA) and the World Health Organization, through the MOU on ciguatera poisoning . Additionally, the IOC maintains a relationship IMO, FAO, WMO, IAEA, and UNEP on the Joint Group of Experts on the Scientific Aspects of Marine Environmental Protection (GESAMP) . The IOC also contributes to the Global Ocean Observing System (GOOS), which is an international collaborative effort to observe the ocean and provide data for scientific research and policy-making . IOC has also built relationship with NGOs and private sectors, including A partnership agreement with the International Monohull Open Class Association , World Ocean Council , and Fugro .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The IOC coordinates with UN, ESCO, WMO, EP through mechanisms to advance research.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: As stated in its constitution, the FAO maintains relations with the UN as a specialized agency (Article XII), and with other international, regional, and national organizations and authorities related to food and agriculture (Article XIII). The FAO may also enter into agreements with Member Nations for the establishment of international institutions dealing with food and agriculture (Article XV) . The FAO engages with a diverse array of institutions to advance its mission. It partners with Member States and various stakeholders, including civil society, the private sector, academia, and research centers, to combat food insecurity and malnutrition . The FAO’s collaboration with academia and research institutions is crucial for mobilizing knowledge and innovations, as well as for providing evidence-based solutions to policy processes . Furthermore, the FAO works closely with international organizations to facilitate partnerships for food and nutrition security, agriculture, and rural development3. For instance, the FAO’s Strategy for Private Sector Engagement aims to strengthen strategic engagement with the private sector towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) . In addition, the FAO is involved in South-South Cooperation, which is a key instrument for delivering on its mandate and achieving the SDGs . This cooperation is facilitated through the FAO’s Partnerships and UN Collaboration Division, which develops strategic cooperation with non-state actors .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The FAO coordinates with UN, XII, XIII, XV through mechanisms to advance research.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: Convention on the Intergovernmental Maritime Consultative Organization (IMO) Secretariat
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The IMO collaborates with a diverse array of organizations to support its maritime governance objectives. It maintains formal relations with 66 intergovernmental organizations, as governed by Articles 25 and 66 of the Convention on the International Maritime Organization , and detailed in resolution A.1168(32) adopted by the IMO Assembly on 15 December 20211 .pdf). This includes cooperation with the UN (UN), with the relationship between the IMO and the UN outlined in Part XV of the IMO Convention, specifically Article 592 . The IMO also engages with non-governmental international organizations that contribute expert advice to IMO Member States on their respective areas of work, with formal relations established as per the provisions contained in the Rules and Guidelines for Consultative Status . Additionally, the IMO supports the implementation of the UN Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development, collaborating with various stakeholders to enhance ocean governance3. These relationships enable the IMO to fulfill its mandate, ensuring the safety, security, and environmental performance of international shipping, and facilitating global maritime cooperation1. The IMO collaborates with the IOC inl research efforts to understand and address human impacts on the ocean’s ecosystems (The IOC coordinates global research efforts to understand and address human impacts on the ocean’s ecosystems, where the IMO contributes with its expertise on maritime aspects1.), including the Global Ocean Oxygen Decade (GOOD) . IMO collabortes with the IOC, IAEA, UNEP, WMO, and others on the GESAMP Working Group 45 on Climate Change and Greenhouse Gas Related Impacts on Contaminants in the Ocean . IMO als collaboration with GEF and UNDP to protect marine biodiversity by preventing the transfer of invasive aquatic species through the GloFouling Partnership project .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The IMO coordinates with UN, XV, Member States, IOC through frameworks to advance research.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: Division for Ocean Affairs and the Law of the Sea (UN DOALOS)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: DOALOS collaborates with key organizations to support ocean governance. It liaises with the International Seabed Authority (ISA), implementing a relationship agreement effective since 25 July 1996, as per UNCLOS Annex III Article 4 and the 1994 Agreement Article 177, detailed in resolution 48/263 . Similarly, DOALOS maintains a relationship with the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (ITLOS), providing administrative support based on an agreement aligned with the Tribunal's Statute Article 5 and the 1994 Agreement Article 178, detailed in resolution 51/204 . Additionally, DOALOS supports the Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf (CLCS) by providing technical assistance and facilities, aiding developing states in their submissions, with its functions detailed in CLCS Rules of Procedure and Annex II of UNCLOS . It also services the Informal Consultative Process (ICP) on Oceans and the Law of the Sea, preparing related reports, with its mandate in resolution 54/33 . Moreover, DOALOS facilitates the Regular Process for Global Reporting and Assessment of the Marine Environment, established in 2002, to enhance scientific understanding and decision-making, involving a Group of Experts and a Working Group, with terms detailed in resolution 57/141 . Moreover, DOALOS provides capacity-building assistance to developing countries in the field of ocean affairs and the law of the sea, through training, fellowships, technical assistance, and financial support .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The DOALOS coordinates with ISA, UN, CLOS, III through mechanisms to advance governance.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The UNFCCC Secretariat maintains collaborative relationships with various UN agencies and international organizations to advance climate action and sustainable development . This collaboration includes working with the UN Development Programme (UNDP) on implementing NDCs under the Paris Agreement, with UNESCO to promote climate change education and research, and with the WHO and WMO to address health risks and improve climate data related to climate change . Additionally, the Secretariat aligns with the UN Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) and the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) as part of the Rio Conventions from the 1992 Earth Summit. They focus on tackling climate change, desertification, and biodiversity loss through initiatives like land degradation neutrality and sustainable management. Strengthened by a 2023 memorandum of understanding, their cooperation is guided by the Joint Liaison Group (JLG), established to enhance synergy and coordination among the Rio Conventions .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with FCCC, DP, NDC, ESCO through frameworks to advance research.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The ISA cooperates with various organizations to achieve its objectives and mandates. It maintains a relationship with the UN (UN), as an observer to the UN General Assembly, based on an agreement in accordance with UNCLOS Article 156, paragraph 2, and the 1994 Agreement Article 169 . Similarly, it maintains a relationship with the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (ITLOS), as the principal judicial organ for the settlement of disputes relating to the activities in the Area, based on an agreement in accordance with UNCLOS Article 187 and the 1994 Agreement Article 178, detailed in resolution 51/205. Additionally, it consults and collaborates with the relevant specialized agencies of the UN, such as the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), and the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission (IOC), as well as other international and regional organizations, such as the International Maritime Organization (IMO), the International Hydrographic Organization (IHO), and the regional fisheries management organizations (RFMOs), on matters of common interest, in accordance with UNCLOS Article 156, paragraph 3, and the 1994 Agreement Article 170 . It also participates in the Informal Consultative Process (ICP) on Oceans and the Law of the Sea, providing inputs and updates on its activities, with its role recognized in resolution 54/33 . Moreover, it contributes to the Regular Process for Global Reporting and Assessment of the Marine Environment, providing data and information on the environmental aspects of the activities in the Area, with its involvement encouraged in resolution 57/141 .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The ISA coordinates with UN, CLOS, ITLOS, FAO through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNEP collaborates with a wide range of organizations to fulfill its objectives. It engages with 193 Member States and various stakeholders through the UN Environment Assembly (UNEA), established in 2013 by resolution 67/251, serving as the highest-level environmental decision-making body . As the primary environmental authority within the UN system, UNEP's relationship with the UN is grounded in resolution 2997 (XXVII), which established UNEP in 1972 . Additionally, UNEP supports multilateral environmental agreements (MEAs) and regional seas conventions and action plans, providing legal and operational frameworks for specific environmental issues and regions, as stipulated in resolution 2997 (XXVII), paragraph 2 c , and resolution 58/240, paragraph 4 of the UN General Assembly . It also collaborates with UN specialized agencies like FAO, IMO, and IOC, and other organizations such as ISA, ITLOS, and RFMOs, addressing shared environmental concerns. Moreover, UNEP contributes to the Regular Process for Global Reporting and Assessment of the Marine Environment, offering data on marine environmental conditions, as recognized in resolution 57/141, paragraph 6 .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with EP, Member States, EA, XXVII through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNDP collaborates with various partners to advance sustainable development. It works with governments, providing policy advice, technical assistance, and financial support, based on the UN Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF) and the Country Programme Documents (CPDs) that outline the country-specific priorities and results . It coordinates with the UN development system, ensuring coherent and effective support to countries, with its Administrator as the Vice-Chair of the UN Sustainable Development Group, which unites the 40 UN entities that contribute to the attainment of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development at the country level . Furthermore, UNDP partners with international financial institutions, mobilizing non-core funding and implementing joint projects, such as the World Bank, the African Development Bank, the Asian Development Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank, with whom UNDP has formal agreements . It likewise collaborates with other UN entities, such as the UN Environment Programme, the UN Human Settlements Programme, the UN Office on Drugs and Crime, and the UN Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women, on various thematic areas and initiatives, while also engaging with the private sector to foster innovation and entrepreneurship, and with foundations, civil society organizations, and goodwill ambassadors, leveraging their knowledge, networks, and resources, through various platforms and initiatives like the SDG Philanthropy Platform, the Business Call to Action, and the UNDP Innovation Facility . These partnerships are essential for UNDP to fulfill its strategic plan and contribute to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with DP, DAF, CPD, SDG through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNCTAD collaborates with various organizations to achieve its objectives and mandates. It engages with 195 Member States and various stakeholders through the UNCTAD conference, held every four years, serving as the highest-level decision-making body on trade and development issues . As the main organ of the General Assembly in the field of trade and development, UNCTAD's relationship with the UN is based on resolution 1995 (XIX), which established UNCTAD in 1964 . Additionally, UNCTAD leads the UN Inter-Agency Cluster on Trade and Productive Capacity, involving 15 UN agencies, providing a mechanism for the coordination of trade and development operations at the national and regional levels within the UN system, as endorsed by the UN Chief Executives Board for Coordination . It also cooperates with other international and regional organizations, such as WTO, OECD, World Bank, ILO, and CITES, UNDP, UNIDO, IMF, etc addressing common trade and development challenges . Moreover, UNCTAD supports the implementation of the UN development agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals, offering research and analysis, technical assistance, intergovernmental consensus-building, and policy advice for developing countries, as recognized in resolution 71/215 .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with CTAD, Member States, XIX, WTO through frameworks to advance research.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNIDO collaborates with various organizations to achieve its objectives and mandates. It works with 170 Member States and various stakeholders through the General Conference, the Industrial Development Board, and the Programme and Budget Committee, which are the policymaking organs of the Organization, as stipulated in Chapter III of the Constitution of UNIDO . As a specialized agency of the UN, UNIDO's relationship with the UN is based on the Agreement between the UN and the UN Industrial Development Organization, which entered into force in 1985, as detailed in resolution 40/180 of the UN General Assembly . It also partners with other UN entities, such as FAO, IAEA, ILO, UNCTAD, UNDP, UNEP, UNESCO, UNFCCC, and WHO .) international financial institutions, such as the African Development Bank, the European Investment Bank and the World Bank , as well as other intergovernmental organizations, such as the African Union, the European Union, the Organization of American States, and the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, addressing common industrial challenges and opportunities . Moreover, UNIDO engages with the private sector, civil society, academia, and media, fostering inclusive and sustainable industrialization .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with IDO, Member States, III, FAO through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The ILO collaborates with various organizations to achieve its objectives. It works closely with its tripartite constituents - governments, employers and workers - through the International Labour Conference, the Governing Body, and the Regional Meetings, which are the supreme organs of the ILO and set its policies and programmes . As the first specialized agency of the UN, the ILO's relationship with the UN is based on the Agreement between the UN and the International Labour Organization, which was approved by the General Assembly in 1946 and by the International Labour Conference in 1947 . Additionally, the ILO cooperates with other UN agencies and regional and subregional organizations, such as the UN Economic and Social Council, the UN Development Group, UNEP, UNIDO, UNDP, UNITAR, the World Bank, the IMF, the OECD, the African Union, the European Union, and the Organization of American States, on various aspects of labour and social issues, as stipulated in Article 12 and Article 13 of the ILO Constitution (https://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---asia/---ro-bangkok/---ilo-hanoi/documents/publication/wcms_818973.pdf; https://www.ilo.org/pardev/partnerships/partnerships-and-relations/interagency-partnerships/lang--en/index.htm). The ILO is member of the UN Cluster on Trade and Productive Capacity through which it works with UNCTAD, ITC, UNIDO and UNOPS to enhance horticulture supply and sustainable tourism to develop business linkages in developing countries It also participates in the Regular Process for Global Reporting and Assessment of the Marine Environment, providing data on the social and economic dimensions of the marine sector, as recognized in resolution 57/141, paragraph .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The ILO coordinates with UN, EP, IDO, DP through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: ITU collaborates with various organizations to achieve its objectives. It engages with 193 Member States and over 900 Sector Members and Associates through the Plenipotentiary Conference, the supreme organ of the ITU, established by Article 8 of the Constitution of the ITU . As the specialized agency of the UN for telecommunications, information and communication technologies, ITU's relationship with the UN is based on the Agreement between the UN and the International Telecommunication Union, signed in 1947 . Additionally, ITU supports the implementation of the World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) outcomes and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, providing a platform for multi-stakeholder dialogue and action on the role of ICTs in development, as recognized by resolution 70/125 of the UN General Assembly³. It also cooperates with other UN specialized agencies, such as UNESCO, WHO, and WMO, and other organizations, such as WTO, OECD, and ICANN, addressing common ICT issues and challenges . Moreover, ITU collaborated with the WMO and UNESCO-IOCJoint on the Joint Task Force on SMART Submarine repeaters equipped with scientific sensors for climate monitoring and disaster risk reduction (tsunami warnings) .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The ITU coordinates with Member States, UN, WSIS, ICT through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNICEF collaborates with a diverse range of organizations to achieve its objectives. It works with 193 Member States and various stakeholders through the Executive Board, serving as the governing body of UNICEF . As the leading UN agency for children's rights, UNICEF's relationship with the UN is based on resolution 57 (I) 57/60, which reaffirmed UNICEF's mandate and role within the UN system . Additionally, UNICEF supports the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC) and other international and regional instruments and mechanisms that advance the rights and well-being of children and young people, as stated in resolution 57/60, paragraph 2 . It also partners with UN agencies and international financial institutions such as WHO, UNESCO, UNHCR, WFP, UNDP, and the World Bank, and other organizations such as the Global Partnership for Education, the Global Fund, and Gavi, addressing common challenges and opportunities for children . Moreover, UNICEF contributes to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, aligning its Strategic Plan 2022-2025 with the Sustainable Development Goals, as endorsed in resolution 70/1 .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with ICEF, Member States, CRC, WHO through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: WHO collaborates with various organizations to achieve its objectives. It works with 194 Member States and various stakeholders through the World Health Assembly (WHA), established in 1948 by the Constitution of the WHO, serving as the supreme decision-making body for health . As a specialized agency within the UN system, WHO's relationship with the UN is based on the Agreement between the UN and the World Health Organization, effective since 10 July 1948, which defines the respective responsibilities and cooperation of the two organizations . Additionally, WHO supports various health-related conventions and treaties, providing legal and normative frameworks for specific health issues and situations, such as the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control and the International Health Regulations . It also collaborates with other UN agencies and partners, such as Gavi, The GFF, the Global Fund, UNAIDS, UNDP, UNFPA, UNICEF, UNITAID, UN Women, World Bank Group and WFP and WHO, addressing common health challenges . Moreover, WHO participates in the Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC), contributing to the coordination and delivery of humanitarian assistance, as endorsed by resolution 46/182 of the UN General Assembly .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The WHO coordinates with Member States, WHA, UN, GFF through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), and the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: OHCHR collaborates with various organizations to promote and protect human rights . It works with the Human Rights Council (HRC), established in 2006 by resolution 60/251, serving as the main intergovernmental body responsible for human rights issues . As the secretariat of the HRC, OHCHR's relationship with the Council is based on resolution 48/141, paragraph 4 (b), which entrusts the High Commissioner with the task of making recommendations to the competent bodies of the UN system in the field of human rights . Additionally, OHCHR supports the treaty bodies and special procedures, providing substantive and technical assistance for the monitoring and implementation of international human rights instruments and standards, as mandated by resolution 48/141, paragraph 4 (a) and (d) . It also cooperates with UN agencies, funds and programmes, as well as regional and national human rights institutions, civil society organizations, and other actors, to enhance coordination and effectiveness of human rights activities throughout the UN system, as stipulated by resolution 48/141, paragraph 4 (h) and (i) . Moreover, OHCHR participates in the Universal Periodic Review (UPR), offering technical and logistical support for the peer review mechanism of the human rights situation of all UN Member States, as established by resolution 60/251, paragraph 5 (e) .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The OHCHR coordinates with HRC, UN, UPR, Member States through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction (UNDRR)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNDRR collaborates with various organizations to implement the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030 . It works with the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), the UN Development Programme (UNDP), and the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) to provide technical support and guidance to Member States and other stakeholders on disaster risk reduction, as stated in paragraph 48 (a) of the Sendai Framework . It also coordinates with the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the UN Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD), and the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) to ensure coherence and synergies among the relevant instruments and frameworks, as stated in paragraph 48 (b) of the Sendai Framework . Additionally, UNDRR engages with the scientific and technological community, the private sector, civil society, and other relevant actors to foster partnerships and innovation for disaster risk reduction, as stated in paragraph 48 (c) and (d) of the Sendai Framework . Moreover, UNDRR supports the Global Platform for Disaster Risk Reduction, the regional and subregional platforms for disaster risk reduction, and the thematic platforms, as well as the UN Scientific and Technical Advisory Group, to facilitate dialogue, cooperation, and knowledge-sharing on disaster risk reduction, as stated in paragraph 49 of the Sendai Framework .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with DRR, OCHA, DP, EP through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The UN Global Compact cooperates with various organizations to achieve its objectives. It works with the UN Secretary-General and the UN Global Compact Board, which provide strategic guidance and oversight for the initiative, as per resolution 73/254, paragraph 15 ([1]. As a voluntary platform for businesses to align with the UN values and principles, the UN Global Compact's relationship with the UN is based on resolution 55/215, which endorsed the initiative in 2000 . Additionally, the UN Global Compact supports the UN's development agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals, providing a framework for business action and partnerships, as affirmed in resolution 70/1, paragraph 67 . It also partners with UN specialized agencies, funds and programmes, such as UNDP, UNICEF, UN Women, and UNEP, as well as other organizations such as the International Labour Organization, the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, and the UN Office on Drugs and Crime, addressing relevant issues and sectors . Moreover, the UN Global Compact engages with its participants and stakeholders, including over 13,000 companies and 3,800 non-business signatories from 160 countries, through its Local Networks, platforms, programmes, and initiatives , as outlined in resolution 73/254, paragraph 16 .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with DP, ICEF, EP through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The IAEA collaborates with various organizations to achieve its objectives. It engages with 178 Member States and various stakeholders through the General Conference, which is the highest policy-making body of the Agency and meets annually to approve the programme and budget, as well as the Board of Governors, which consists of 35 Member States and meets five times a year to examine and make recommendations to the General Conference on the IAEA's accounts, programme and budget, and to consider applications for membership . As an autonomous organization within the UN system, the IAEA's relationship with the UN is guided by an agreement signed in 1957, which stipulates that the Agency shall report annually to the General Assembly and, when appropriate, to the Security Council, and shall cooperate with the Economic and Social Council and other specialized agencies . Additionally, the IAEA supports the implementation of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) and other international legal instruments and initiatives related to nuclear safety, security, and cooperation, providing verification and inspection services, technical assistance, and policy guidance for Member States, as detailed in the IAEA Statute, Article III . It also cooperates with other UN agencies and organizations, such as WHO, FAO, UNEP, and OECD/NEA, as well as regional and intergovernmental organizations, such as the European Union, the African Union, and the Organization of American States, addressing common nuclear issues and challenges, as recognized in various resolutions and agreements , , .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The IAEA coordinates with Member States, UN, NPT, III through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The WMO collaborates with key organizations to fulfill its objectives. It engages with 193 Member States and various stakeholders through the World Meteorological Congress, serving as the highest-level meteorological decision-making body . As the primary meteorological authority within the UN system, WMO's relationship with the UN is grounded in Part XII, Article 25 of the Convention of the World Meteorological Organization , pursuant to Article 57 of the Charter of the UN . Additionally, WMO supports National Meteorological and Hydrological Services (NMHSs) and advances the application of meteorology and hydrology in many societal and economic areas . Pursuant to Part XIII, Article 26 of its convention, WMO collaborates with UN specialized agencies, multilateral development banks, climate funds and others, addressing shared meteorological concerns . Moreover, WMO contributes to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction, and the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change . Furthermore, WMO maintains a relationship with the public, private, and academic sectors operating in the global weather arena through its Public-Private Engagement (PPE) initiative . This initiative encourages and enables Members to pursue mutually beneficial partnerships and engagement with all sectors and stakeholders in order to enhance weather, climate, and water services for businesses, individuals, and society as a whole . Finally, WMO facilitates the Voluntary Cooperation Programme (VCP), which focuses on meeting urgent needs of Members through direct financing, small grants and transfer of expertise and technology .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The WMO coordinates with Member States, UN, XII, NMHS through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: OECD collaborates with various organizations to promote economic co-operation and development. It maintains relations with the European Communities, established by the Treaties of Paris and Rome of 18th April, 1951, and 25th March, 1957, as defined in Supplementary Protocol No. 1 to the Convention on the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD Convention), article 13 . It also enters into agreements with Members, non-member States and international organizations, as provided for in OECD Convention, article 5 (c) . Additionally, OECD participates in the activities of other international organizations or institutions, such as the UN, the World Bank, the IMF, and the WTO, in a manner consistent with its obligations, as stated in OECD Convention, article 1 (c) . It also contributes to the economic development of both Member and non-member countries in the process of economic development, by appropriate means and, in particular, by the flow of capital to those countries, as agreed in OECD Convention, article 2 (e) . Moreover, OECD supports the further expansion of world trade on a multilateral, non-discriminatory basis, as one of the most important factors favouring the economic development of countries and the improvement of international economic relations, as affirmed in OECD Convention, article 1 (c) .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The OECD coordinates with UN, IMF, WTO through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The WBG collaborates with a wide range of partners and stakeholders, working closely with its five constituent institutions to achieve its defined objectives . The WBG also engages with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), which shares the same premises and some common services, and cooperates on various policy and operational issues . Furthermore, it partners with other multilateral and bilateral development agencies, civil society organizations, private sector entities, foundations, and academic institutions, to leverage knowledge, resources, and expertise for development solutions . The WBG participates in various global initiatives and platforms, such as the Global Environment Facility (GEF) , the Global Partnership for Education (GPE) , the Global Financing Facility (GFF) , and the Global Infrastructure Facility (GIF) , to address specific development challenges and opportunities .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The WBG coordinates with IMF, GEF, GPE, GFF through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The IMF collaborates with various institutions to achieve its goals and objectives, working closely with the World Bank in program design and monitoring. This collaboration is based on the IMF’s mandate and limited resources, drawing on the expertise of the World Bank and other relevant institutions as detailed in the IMF Pamphlet Series - No. 47, under the section “Collaboration with Other Institutions in Program Design and Monitoring” . The IMF also maintains a relationship with the UN Development Programme (UNDP) and the International Labour Organization (ILO). The IMF assists member countries in integrating social policies in the macroeconomic framework developed in close collaboration with these institutions. Collaboration between the IMF and the World Trade Organization (WTO) has been substantially strengthened on trade issues. This is detailed in the IEO Update on the IMF’s involvement in international trade policies. The IMF’s engagement with regional development banks and bilateral donor agencies is also noteworthy . Coordination between these institutions helps to minimize the burden on member countries, especially those with low administrative capacity that engage with multiple IOs .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The IMF coordinates with UN, DP, ILO, WTO through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The IHO collaborates with various organisations to achieve its objectives. It engages with its 99 Member States and other stakeholders through the Assembly . The IHO enjoys observer status in the UN and is particularly active in a number of its subordinate organisations, most notably the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) and the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission (IOC) . Additionally, the IHO supports the implementation of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), especially SDG 14 on Life Below Water, by providing hydrographic data and information for safe, secure and sustainable use of the oceans . It also cooperates with other UN specialized agencies and programmes, such as IMO, IOC, UNEP, UNDP, and WMO, and other organizations, such as ISA, ITLOS, IALA, and ICG/IOC, addressing shared hydrographic and oceanographic issues . Moreover, the IHO contributes to the UN Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development (2021-2030) , offering expertise and standards for ocean mapping and observation, as acknowledged in UN resolution 72/73, paragraph 14 .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The IHO coordinates with Member States, UN, IMO, IOC through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: ICES collaborates with various organizations, partners and stakeholders to achieve its defined objectives. ICES has established formal cooperation agreements with the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission of UNESCO (IOC/UNESCO) and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN (FAO) . As an observer to the UN General Assembly, ICES contributes and engages actively in relevant work, such as working towards the Sustainable Development Goals ; contributing to the UN Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development (UNESCO/IOC); the Informal Consultations of States Parties to the UN Fish Stocks Agreement; and the UN Open-ended Informal Consultative Process in Oceans and the Law of the Sea . ICES also expands its human capacity building services thematically and geographically by organizing a series of training courses for the Large Marine Ecosystem practitioners under the GEF/UNDP ‘Strengthening Global Governance of Large Marine Ecosystems and Their Coasts through Enhanced Sharing and Application of LME/ICM/MPA Knowledge and Information Tools’ LME-LEARN project .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The ICES coordinates with UN, ESCO, IOC, FAO through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: The Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: IPBES collaborates with key organisations to support biodiversity and ecosystem services. It has an institutional link with the UN Environment Programme, the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN and the UN Development Programme, based on a collaborative partnership arrangement approved by the Plenary in its decision IPBES-2/8 . Similarly, IPBES has memoranda of understanding with several strategic partners, such as Future Earth, the Global Biodiversity Information Facility, the Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research, and the International Union for Conservation of Nature, as requested by the Plenary in its decision IPBES-4/4 . Additionally, IPBES engages with various multilateral environmental agreements related to biodiversity and ecosystem services, such as the Convention on Biological Diversity, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, the Convention on Migratory Species, the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands, and the World Heritage Convention, as reported by the Executive Secretary in document IPBES/5/INF/16 . It also involves a large number of NGOs, organizations, conventions and civil society groupings as observers in the formal IPBES process, with several thousand individual stakeholders contributing to and benefiting from its work . Moreover, IPBES supports the recognition and engagement of Indigenous peoples and local communities and their knowledge systems in its activities, as outlined in its approach adopted by the Plenary in its decision IPBES-4/1 .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The IPBES coordinates with UN, INF, NGO through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) collaborates with key organizations to support climate change governance. It liaises with the UN (UN), implementing a relationship agreement effective since its establishment in 1988 , as per the UN's mandate to provide policymakers with regular assessments of the scientific basis of climate change, its impacts, future risks, and adaptation and mitigation options. Similarly, IPCC maintains a relationship with the UN Development Programme (UNDP), providing vital scientific information to limit climate change and establish a strong link between sustainable economic development, climate change, and vulnerability . Additionally, IPCC supports the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) by assessing the scientific literature and providing vital scientific information to the climate change process . It also services the Conference of the Parties (COP) and the Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice (SBSTA) , by preparing related reports within its mandate. Moreover, IPCC facilitates the assessment process through its Task Force on Greenhouse Gas Inventories, carrying out important work on methodologies for estimating and reporting GHG emissions .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The IPCC coordinates with UN, DP, WMO, EP through mechanisms to advance governance.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The WTO cooperates with various institutions to promote trade and development. It works with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank, based on the coherence mandate in the Marrakesh Decision of 1994 , to ensure consistency and complementarity of global economic policies . Likewise, the WTO collaborates with the UN (UN) and its specialized agencies, such as the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), the World Health Organization (WHO), and the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), under the arrangements for effective cooperation signed in 1995, to address the linkages between trade and other policy areas, as specified in Article V of the WTO Agreement . Furthermore, the WTO partners with the International Trade Centre (ITC), a joint agency of the WTO and the UN, to provide trade-related technical assistance and capacity building for developing countries, as stated in the Doha Ministerial Declaration of 2001 . It also engages with the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU), an international organization of national parliaments, to enhance the parliamentary dimension of the WTO and foster dialogue and accountability on trade issues, as agreed in the Memorandum of Understanding of 2018 . Additionally, the WTO participates in various collaborative initiatives with like-minded groups of members and other stakeholders, such as the Joint Statement Initiative on E-commerce , the Joint Statement on Investment Facilitation , and the COVAX Facility on COVID-19 vaccines , to advance discussions and actions on emerging and pressing trade challenges.
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The WTO coordinates with IMF, UN, CTAD, FAO through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: IOM cooperates with various partners to advance migration governance and, in particular, achieve the 2030 Agenda. It engages with the UN (UN), implementing a relationship agreement effective since 19 September 2016, as per the UN General Assembly Resolution 70/296. Similarly, IOM collaborates with the UN Development Programme (UNDP), providing technical support and policy advice . Additionally, IOM works with the World Health Organization (WHO), promoting the health of migrants and refugees . It also participates in the Global Migration Group (GMG), contributing to inter-agency coordination and coherence, with its terms of reference in the GMG Principles of Working Arrangements . Moreover, IOM supports the Global Forum on Migration and Development (GFMD), facilitating dialogue and cooperation among stakeholders, involving a Steering Group and a Support Unit, with its objectives and modalities in the GFMD Operating Modalities .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The IOM coordinates with UN, DP, WHO, GMG through mechanisms to advance governance.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNOPS works with a variety of partners to support sustainable development operations in developing countries and manage portfolios financed by its partners . It establishes and develops strategic relationships with key partners, including the UN family, governments, non-governmental organizations, academia and the private sector. It also has global liaison offices in Bangkok, Brussels, Nordics, Geneva, Nairobi, Tokyo and Washington, D.C., to facilitate partnership development with regional and international organizations, such as the Asian Development Bank, the European Union, the World Bank, the Green Climate Fund, the UN Environment Programme, the UN-Habitat and the United States Agency for International Development . Furthermore, UNOPS provides meaningful technical expertise to countries in the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, supplementing their own capacities, improving efficiency and transparency, reducing risks, boosting cost-effectiveness and ensuring quality. Additionally, UNOPS manages partnerships, trust funds and project portfolios that support people and communities around the world, such as the Global Fund to Fight Aids, Tuberculosis and Malaria, the Stop TB Partnership, the UN-Water Interagency Trust Fund, the Water Supply and Sanitation Collaborative Council, and the Enhanced Integrated Framework .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with OPS, TB through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: UN Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women (UN-Women)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UN-Women collaborates with key institutions to advance gender equality and women's empowerment. It supports UN Member States as they set global standards for achieving gender equality, and works with governments and civil society to design laws, policies, programmes and services needed to ensure that the standards are effectively implemented and truly benefit women and girls worldwide . Similarly, UN-Women liaises with the UN Development Programme (UNDP), implementing a relationship agreement effective since 1 January 2011, as per General Assembly resolution 64/289 , which established UN Women as a composite entity of the UN system, comprising the Division for the Advancement of Women, the International Research and Training Institute for the Advancement of Women, the Office of the Special Adviser on Gender Issues and Advancement of Women, and the UN Development Fund for Women (Paragraph 53). Additionally, UN-Women facilitates linkages and influences between women’s lived experiences and efforts with regional intergovernmental policy and programme processes, and leverages spaces for women leaders to directly engage regional institutions, participate in mediation and other conflict resolution and peace initiatives . It also services the Commission on the Status of Women (CSW) %20of%2021%20June%201946.) with its mandate in Economic and Social Council resolution 11(II) of 21 June 1946 by preparing related reports. Moreover, UN-Women maintains a relationship with the Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) , providing substantive support and servicing its sessions, with its functions detailed in the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women and its Optional Protocol.
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with Member States, DP, CSW, II through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: WIPO cooperates with various organisations to promote and protect intellectual property rights. It works closely with the World Trade Organization (WTO), implementing the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) , which sets minimum standards for IP protection and enforcement, as per the WIPO-WTO Cooperation Agreement of 1995 . Similarly, WIPO maintains a relationship with the UN (UN) and its specialised agencies, such as the UN Development Programme (UNDP), the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), and the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), to align its strategies and objectives with the UN's 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, as per the WIPO General Assembly Resolution of 2016 . Additionally, WIPO supports the WIPO Intergovernmental Committee on Intellectual Property and Genetic Resources, Traditional Knowledge and Folklore (IGC) , which aims to reach an agreement on the protection of these forms of IP, with its mandate and work program detailed in Item 20 of the WIPO General Assembly Decision of 2019 . It also services the WIPO Standing Committee on the Law of Trademarks, Industrial Designs and Geographical Indications (SCT) , which deals with the development of international norms and standards in these areas.
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The WIPO coordinates with WTO, TRIPS, IP, UN through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNFPA works with various partners to advance sexual and reproductive health and rights. It partners with other UN agencies through joint programmes, multi-donor trust funds and other funding arrangements, such as UNICEF, UN Women, UNDP and others, to deliver on the Sustainable Development Goals and the 2030 Agenda . It also engages with international financial institutions to scale-up financing and leverage their expertise and influence, such as the World Bank Group and the African Development Bank, supporting governments in both their loan and grant implementations in line with national development priorities . Furthermore, UNFPA collaborates with civil society organizations, foundations, academia, private sector and media to advocate, mobilize resources and implement programmes for its three transformative results .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with FPA, ICEF, DP through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UN-Habitat establishes and strengthens strategic relationships with a diverse range of partners at national, regional, and international levels, including political actors, civil society, professional organizations, and the private sector . It works with partners through the World Urban Forum , multi-stakeholder thematic partnerships, and advisory boards. These partnerships include the Cities and Climate Change Initiative , Gender Equality Network , Global Alliance for Urban Crisis , Global Housing Strategy Platform , Global Land Tool Network (GLTN), and others. UN-Habitat also services the World Urban Campaign, an advocacy and partnership platform to raise awareness about positive urban change . Furthermore, UN-Habitat partners with sister agencies across the UN, such as UNDESA, UNDP, and UNRCOs, as well as with a large network of local and national partners across the globe to advance SDG localization .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with GLTN, DESA, DP, RCO through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: WFP cooperates with various institutions to achieve its goals and objectives of eradicating hunger and malnutrition. It works closely with other UN agencies and international organizations, as stated in Article III of the General Regulations of the WFP . It has a special relationship with the other two Rome-based UN agencies – FAO and IFAD – with which it shares a common vision of promoting food security. It also has a strong operational partnership with UNHCR for providing food assistance to refugees and internally displaced people. Moreover, WFP collaborates with UNDP and other development partners to support countries' self-defined priorities and accelerate climate action, as part of the UN Development Assistance Framework. Furthermore, WFP engages with other international and regional organizations, such as ECHO, OAS and ICRC, to deliver humanitarian aid and enhance resilience. Additionally, WFP partners with UNV and Online Volunteers to support its work to achieve Zero Hunger .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The WFP coordinates with UN, III, FAO, IFAD through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNWTO cooperates with various institutions to promote sustainable and responsible tourism . It partners with the European Union (EU), implementing a framework agreement signed in Brussels on 28 February 2018, . Likewise, UNWTO maintains a relationship with the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), collaborating on projects related to rural development and food security, based on a memorandum of understanding signed in 2020 . Furthermore, UNWTO supports the World Trade Organization (WTO), contributing to the trade and development agenda and the Aid for Trade initiative . It also engages with the UN system, participating in the UN System Chief Executives Board for Coordination (UNCEB) and the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) , preparing joint reports and recommendations. Additionally, UNWTO facilitates the Partnerships in Education to enhance education and training capabilities in tourism, involving certified programmes and affiliate members.
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with WTO, EU, FAO, CEB through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: UN Research Institute for Social Development (UNRISD)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNRISD engages with various institutions to advance social development research and policy. It works closely with the UN system, especially the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA) , the UN Development Programme (UNDP), and the UN Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC), to contribute to UN agendas and processes, such as the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development . It also collaborates with other UN agencies, funds and programmes, such as UN Women , UNICEF , and UNFPA , on specific research projects and events, as detailed in its annual reports. Furthermore, UNRISD partners with academic institutions, the private sector, think tanks, civil society organisations, and foundations, to co-produce and disseminate knowledge on social development issues . Additionally, UNRISD organises regional roundtables on the social sciences and social issues in development, to strengthen its links with other research networks .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with RISD, DESA, DP, ECOSOC through mechanisms to advance research.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: Secretariat of the Basel, Rotterdam and Stockholm Conventions (BRS)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The BRS Secretariat cooperates with key entities to support the sound management of chemicals and waste. It is administered by the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN (FAO), as per Article 16 of the Basel Convention , Article 19 of the Rotterdam Convention and Article 20 of the Stockholm Convention . It also implements memoranda of understanding with UNEP and FAO, clarifying the institutional relationship and responsibilities of the entities . Furthermore, the BRS Secretariat coordinates with other international bodies, such as the Strategic Approach to International Chemicals Management (SAICM), the Minamata Convention on Mercury, the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer, and the World Health Organization (WHO), to promote synergies and avoid duplication of efforts . It also engages with various stakeholders, such as industry, civil society, academia and media, to raise awareness and mobilize resources for the implementation of the conventions . It also coordinates with the International Seabed Authority (ISA), the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (ITLOS), the Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf (CLCS), the Informal Consultative Process (ICP) on Oceans and the Law of the Sea, and the Regular Process for Global Reporting and Assessment of the Marine Environment . Furthermore, the BRS Secretariat engages with stakeholders, such as regional centres, non-governmental organizations, industry associations, and scientific institutions, to provide technical assistance, capacity building, and information exchange .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The BRS coordinates with UN, EP, FAO, SAICM through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: Secretariat of the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The CBD Secretariat collaborates with key organizations to support biodiversity conservation. It is institutionally linked to UN Environment, its host institution, as per decision II/19 . The Secretariat also liaises with the UN Development Programme (UNDP) and the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) to host the NBSAP Forum, through generous funding provided by the Global Environmental Facility (GEF) . Furthermore, the Secretariat has established Memoranda of Cooperation with numerous entities, outlining formally agreed activities or targets . Guided by Article 22 of the Convention , the Secretariat has also established liaison groups with the secretariats of the Rio Conventions (Joint Liaison Group) and those of the biodiversity-related conventions (Liaison Group of Biodiversity-related Conventions) , as well as for thematic areas, such as the Inter-agency Liaison Group on Invasive Alien Species . The Executive Secretary of the Secretariat is accountable to the Conference of the Parties for programme delivery and policy-related issues and to the Executive Director of UNEP for administrative and financial issues .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The CBD coordinates with UN, II, DP, EP through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: Secretariat of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: CITES cooperates with various institutions to ensure the conservation and sustainable use of wildlife. It works closely with the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), which provides administrative and financial support to the CITES Secretariat, as per the Memorandum of Understanding signed in 1976 and revised in 1983 . It also coordinates with other biodiversity-related conventions, such as the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), the Convention on Migratory Species (CMS), and the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands, through joint work plans, liaison groups, and mutual representation, as per Resolution Conf. 13.3 (Rev. CoP18) . Furthermore, CITES collaborates with international organizations and initiatives, such as the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), the World Trade Organization (WTO), the World Customs Organization (WCO), and the International Consortium on Combating Wildlife Crime (ICCWC), to enhance technical expertise, trade regulation, enforcement, and capacity-building Additionally, CITES engages with non-governmental organizations, civil society, and the private sector, to promote awareness, participation, and compliance .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The CITES coordinates with UN, EP, CBD, CMS through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: Secretariat of the Convention on Migratory Species (CMS)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The CMS Secretariat works with various partners to implement the Convention and conserve migratory species. It cooperates with the secretariats of other biodiversity-related MEAs, such as CBD, CITES, Ramsar, and UNCCD, to harmonize policies and activities , as per Paragraph 4(b) of Article IX of the Convention and resolution 11.10 . It also collaborates with other inter-governmental bodies, such as UNESCO, IWC, and ITTO, to promote joint initiatives and projects on specific species or habitats, as per resolution 12.7 . It engages with non-governmental organizations, such as IUCN, BLI, OceanCare, and IFAW, to support scientific research, conservation action, and public awarenes . It partners with the private sector, such as TUI AG, to raise funds and foster corporate social responsibility, following a code of conduct adopted in resolution 10.21 . It participates in the IPBES as an observer and contributes to its assessments and work programme . It also supports the development and implementation of regional and thematic agreements and initiatives under the Convention, such as EAAFP, WHMSI, and SCF, as per Article IV and V of the Convention and Paragraph 6 of resolution 12.3 .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The CMS coordinates with MEA, CBD, CITES, UN through mechanisms to advance research.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: IFAD partners with various organizations to achieve its mission of ending hunger and promoting food security through sustainable agriculture. This relationship is guided by Article 8 of the Agreement Establishing the International Fund for Agricultural Development . It works closely with the UN Rome-based agencies – the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the World Food Programme (WFP) – with whom it shares a common vision and supports the Committee on World Food Security (CFS). It also collaborates with other UN programmes and funds such as UN Women . Beyond the UN System, IFAD partners with multilateral development banks and international financial institutions, such as the African Development Bank, the Islamic Development Bank, the OPEC Fund for International Development and the World Bank. IFAD also works with regional organizations such as ASEAN, COMESA, ECOWAS, the European Union and Mercosur; multilateral climate and environment funds, such as the GCF and GEF; and other multilateral organizations, such as the OECD . In addition, IFAD facilitates the Global Environment Facility (GEF), established in 1991, to enhance environmental sustainability and resilience . It also engages with the Green Climate Fund (GCF), established in 2010, to mobilise climate finance and support adaptation and mitigation actions .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The IFAD coordinates with UN, FAO, WFP, CFS through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: ITC works with various institutions to achieve its goals of trade promotion and development. It is a joint agency of the WTO and the UN, operating under the guidance of the UN General Assembly and the WTO General Council . It also cooperates with the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), the UN Development Programme (UNDP), and other UN specialized agencies and programmes, as well as regional and intergovernmental organizations, to implement trade-related technical assistance and capacity-building activities . Furthermore, ITC collaborates with the International Trade Centre Trust Fund (ITF), which is a multi-donor trust fund that supports ITC’s projects and programmes. Additionally, ITC maintains relations with other trade-related institutions, such as the Codex Alimentarius Commission, the International Labour Organization (ILO), the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), and the World Health Organization (WHO), to address various aspects of trade and development, as well as with the private sector, Governments, civil societies and philanthropic foundations, multilateral partners, academia, training and research partners, business support organizations, and regional partners .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The ITC coordinates with WTO, UN, CTAD, DP through mechanisms to advance research.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: Secretariat of the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The UNCCD Secretariat collaborates with various institutions to implement its goals and objectives. This collaboration is guided by Articles 8 & 25 of the UNCCD Convention . The UNCCD works closely with the Rio conventions and the Global Environment Facility to develop common indicators and synergies in reporting processes and capacity-building . The Secretariat also collaborates with other UN entities on issues of food security, climate change, land degradation and restoration, forests, gender, drought, sand and dust storms, and migration . In addition, it has established a strategic working partnership with the UN Development Programme (UNDP) to raise awareness and catalyze international cooperation to address the needs of the world’s poorest living in the drylands, particularly under scenarios of climate change .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with CCD, DP through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The UNU collaborates with various institutions to advance its research and training objectives. It functions under the joint sponsorship of the UN and UNESCO, through a central body and a network of centres and programmes, as per Article I, paragraph 1 of its Charter . It also coordinates its activities with the UN and its agencies, such as UNITAR (Article VI, paragraph 1 f), UNIDO, as well as as as well as regional and national bodies, such as the European Union, the African Development Bank, and the Japanese Government. It may receive voluntary contributions and assistance from governments, organizations, and individuals, and mobilizes resources from various donors and funding agencies, such as the German Government, the World Bank, and the International Climate Initiative, to support its academic projects and core operations (Article IX, paragraphs 1-2). Additionally, the UNU designates certain institutions and centres, particularly in developing countries, as associated institutions of the UNU, on terms and conditions decided by the Council . Moreover, UNU partners with academic institutions and networks around the world, such as Maastricht University, the University of Tokyo, and the International Partnership for the Satoyama Initiative, to conduct joint research, education, and training programmes .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with ESCO, ITAR, VI, IDO through mechanisms to advance research.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The Ramsar Secretariat collaborates with various institutions to achieve its objectives. It is based at the headquarters of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) in Gland, Switzerland . The Secretariat develops cooperation with other conventions, intergovernmental institutions, and national and international NGOs . It also works to strengthen collaboration with the World Bank and UN agencies, particularly UNEP, UNDP, FAO, WHO, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), and the Intergovernmental Science Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES). This collaboration is detailed in the draft resolution on enhancing the Convention's visibility (Ramsar COP14 Doc.18.8 Rev.2) . Furthermore, the Secretariat has interface procedures with the Joint Environment Unit (JEU) of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) and the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The IUCN coordinates with NGO, UN, EP, DP through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: The Minamata Convention collaborates with key organizations to protect human health and the environment from the adverse effects of mercury. It enhances cross-linkages with relevant international processes and bodies, such as the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the World Health Organization . The Convention also cooperates with the secretariats of the Basel, Rotterdam, and Stockholm Conventions 9https://enb.iisd.org/minamata-convention-mercury-cop5-1Nov2023). The UN Development Programme (UNDP) provides support to conduct Minamata Initial Assessment (MIA) and develop ASGM National Action Plans (NAPs), to undertake activities to reduce emissions of mercury and mercury compounds to the atmosphere from point sources and from ASGM, and to phase out mercury-containing products in the healthcare sector 9https://www.undp.org/chemicals-waste/chemicals-and-waste/minamata-convention). These relationships enable the Convention to fulfill its role as a global legally binding instrument on mercury to address the risks to human health and the environment from mercury pollution.
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with FCCC, DP, MIA, ASGM through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNOOSA cooperates with various organisations to promote and facilitate peaceful international cooperation in outer space. It works closely with the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (COPUOS), providing substantive secretariat services and implementing its decisions and recommendations, as per General Assembly resolution 1472 (XIV) of 12 December 1959 . It also maintains a relationship with the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), coordinating on issues related to global navigation satellite systems and space weather, as detailed in document A/AC.105/2019/CRP.14 . Additionally, UNOOSA partners with the UN Development Programme (UNDP), supporting the use of space applications for sustainable development, particularly in developing economies . It also collaborates with the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), contributing to the Global Environmental Outlook and the Eye on Earth initiatives . Moreover, UNOOSA engages with other UN entities, intergovernmental organisations, non-governmental organisations, academic institutions, and private sector actors, through various agreements, mechanisms, platforms, and initiatives, such as the Inter-Agency Meeting on Outer Space Activities, the International Committee on Global Navigation Satellite Systems, the International Charter on Space and Major Disasters, and the Access to Space for All initiative .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with OOSA, COPUOS, XIV, ICAO through mechanisms to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Institutions: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC)
Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: UNODC collaborates with various institutions to implement its goals and objectives. It works with the Asian Development Bank on anti-money-laundering and sustainable livelihoods . It also cooperates with the OPEC Fund for International Development on HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment, and the NATO-Russian Council on issues related to Afghanistan . UNODC has also established Judicial Regional Platforms in the regions of the Sahel and the Indian Ocean . It also partners with UN-Habitat, UN Women, UNEP, UN Development Programme, United Cities and Local Governments (UCLG), European Forum on Urban Security (EFUS), NGO Alliance on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice, Peace in Our Cities, UNCAC Coalition, Vienna NGO Committee on Drugs, and others .
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with ODC, OPEC, HIV, AIDS through frameworks to advance development.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support

Cleaned Practical Vertical Coordination: Collaboration with UN specialized agencies, Multilateral cooperation and partnerships, Joint research and development initiatives, Coordinated policy advocacy, Shared capacity building programs, Inter-agency agreements and MOUs, Collaborative environmental monitoring and management, Exchange of knowledge and best practices, Co-funding and financial partnerships, Networking and information exchange platforms
Summarized Vertical Coordination: The UN coordinates with MOU through mechanisms to advance research.
Themes: Multi-Level Governance Structures;Collaboration with External Entities;Technical and Capacity-Building Support
